LALIT AND INDU MALHOTRA, JJ .) 787 GANESH Appellant; Versus SUDHIRKUMAR SHRIVASTAVA AND OTHERS .. Respondents. Civil Appeals Nos. 4031-32 of 2019t, Order dated April 22, 2019 A. Family and Personal Laws - Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 - S. 13-B - Divorce by mutual consent - Binding effect of compromise/settlement between parties - Extent of - Compromise/Settlement arrived at between parties before the court, held, must be effectuated in complete sense - Parties arrived at a settlement and decided to withdraw the cases filed by each of the parties against the other - However, respondent wife despite having given an undertaking in terms of the consent terms, declined to withdraw the proceedings - Considering abovesaid legal position, FIR as well as proceedings initiated at the instance of wife directed to be quashed (Paras 5 and 6) Gian Singh v. State of Punjab, (2012) 10 sec 303 : (2012) 4 sec (Civ) 1188 : (2013) 1 sec (Cri) 160 : (2012) 2 sec (L&S) 988, relied on Ganesh v. Sudhir Kumar Shrivastava, 2018 SCC 0nLine Born 19739, considered Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273 : (2014) 3 SCC (Cri) 449, cited B. Family and Personal Laws - Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 - Ss. 13-B and 25 - Divorce by mutual consent - Right of wife to give up claim for maintenance - Scope of- Children's rights cannot be given up - Though, wife could give up any claim so far as maintenance or permanent alimony or stridhan is concerned, but she could not have given up the rights which vest in the minor daughter insofar as maintenance and other issues are concerned - Exercising powers under Art. 142 of the Constitution, Para 6 of the consent terms affecting rights of daughter set aside by the Supreme Court (Paras 7 and 8) SK-D/64316/SVR Advocates who appeared in this case : Santosh Paul, Senior Advocate (Amicus Curiae), Subhranshu Dash and Ms Shreya Mahalwar, Advocates, for the Appellant; Ms Rukmini Bobde (Advocate-on-Record) (Amicus Curiae), for the Respondents. Heard Mr Santosh Paul, learned Senior Counsel who assisted this Court as Amicus Curiae on behalf of the appellant husband and Ms Rukmini Bobde, learned counsel who assisted this Court as Amicus Curiae on behalf of the respondent wife. 2. In the present matter, the parties had entered into consent terms. The Principal Judge, Family Court, Aurangabad took the consent terms on record in Petition No. A-192/2017 and passed order dated 8-11-2017 in terms thereof. The text of the order passed by the Principal Judge, Family Court, Aurangabad reads as under: "Petition was filed by Applicant 1 for divorce, according to Sections 13(1)(i-a) and (i-b) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, against Applicant 2 in the Court. While the case was pending, the two parties were sent to the counsellor. According to the counsellor's report, Ext. 11, both the parties decided to take divorce themselves and the counsellor after independence and with mutual consent after the efforts of the counsellor failed. Marriage of Applicants 1 and 2 on 9-12-2019 Radhakrishna Mangal Karya, Crnco, Aurangabad was conducted as per Hindu Dharma and Customary. From this marriage, the girl, namely, Vedika was born on 1-4-2014. The girl is currently under the custody of Applicant 1. Applicants 1 and 2 are separated from date 1-6-2014 due to mutual differences of opinion and nature. After the efforts of the counsellor failed, they have voluntarily converted the original petition in accordance with Section 13-B of the Hindu Marriage Act. After the marriage counsellor attempts, there is no possibility of cohabitation but the applicant is ready to take divorce according to the terms and condition made in Ext. 12 of 1 and 2. Judgment 1. Amendment application is approved. 2. Marriage completed on date 9-12-2012 of Applicants 1 and 2 is dismissed by decree in accordance with Section 13-B of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. 3. Under the terms and conditions of Ext. 12, the terms and conditions of this judgment should be considered as part of this judgment. 4. The parties from both sides should spend their money. 5. From this make the decree. Consent Sheet Ext. 12 (1) The marriage of the applicant and the non-applicant has been done on the basis of Hindu theology (sic rites) in Aurangabad on 9-12-2012. a b C d e f g (2) The applicant and the non-taxman are separated from each h other on 1-6-2004. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. SUDHIRKUMAR SHRIVASTAVA 789 (3) The applicant and the non-applicant have a daughter Vedika (birth date 1-4-2014) from this marriage for 3 years 3 months. (4) Currently the girl Vedika is in the custody with applicant i.e. the mother and will remain in the future with applicant, it is accepted to non-applicant. (5) The applicant has released the right of monthly maintenance, permanent alimony and stridhan on non-applicant. (6) The applicant has released the right of monthly maintenance to the daughter with the non-applicant. The applicant has fully accepted responsibility for the child's livelihood, education and health. (7) Both of them have agreed that the non-applicant will not meet his daughter which is in the custody of the applicant in the future, and will not make any civil or criminal claim in any court to get custody and visitation right of the daughter. (8) The applicant shall not show any right in any property or movable property, will never claim in any civil or criminal nature in any court, to get home from the non-applicant in future . (9) Both of them will no longer have to pay for each other in the form of money or things in the future. (10) The applicant has lodged a complaint against the non- applicant and his two relatives at Taluka Pathri District Parbhani. She will take the complaint back. (11) The non-applicant had filed the Registered Darkhast bearing No. 06/2017 in this Hon'ble Court. The said petition he is withdrawing herewith. (12) As mentioned above there is no matter pending in any Hon'ble Court between the parties. (13) Both of them will not claim and will not file any petition in the cause due to past events. Abovementioned consent is agreed to applicant and non-applicant and hence this consent terms is converted as per Section 13-B of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 for divorce." 3. The appellant husband thereafter filed Contempt Petition No. 304 of 2018 submitting inter alia that Respondents 1 to 4 had not followed certain directions issued by this Court in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar 1 and that the respondent wife despite having given an undertaking in terms of Para 10 of the consent terms, had not withdrawn the proceedings. 4. The contempt petition having been dismissed, the appeal preferred therefrom was also dismissed2 by the High Court. 1 (2014) 8 sec 213: (2014) 3 sec (Cri) 449 2 Ganesh v. Without going into the question whether the appeal was maintainable or not, in our view, appropriate course to be adopted in the matter is to effectuate the understanding as culled out in Para 10 of the consent terms. If the parties had a arrived at a settlement and decided to withdraw the cases filed by each of the parties against the other, the compromise ought to be effectuated in complete sense. 6. The law on the point is well-settled by the decision of this Court in Gian Singh v. State of Punjab 3 • Leaving aside the technicalities, we therefore deem it appropriate to quash the proceedings which were initiated at the instance of the respondent wife i.e. FIR No. 148 of 2015 dated 4-9-2015 registered with Police Station Pathri District Parbhani. Further proceedings in said FIR now stand quashed. 7. Before we part with, we must also express our reservation insofar as Para 6 is concerned, which was incorporated in the order on 8-11-2017 by the Principal Judge, Family Court, Aurangabad. It was certainly open to the wife to give up any claim so far as maintenance or permanent alimony or stridhan is concerned but she could not have given up the rights which vest in the daughter insofar as maintenance and other issues are concerned. 8. We, therefore, exercising our powers under Article 142 of the Constitution of India, set aside Para 6 of the consent terms. Rest of the order stands unaltered and ought to be given effect to. 9. With the aforesaid view, the appeals stand allowed to the aforesaid extent. We express our sincere gratitude to Mr Santosh Paul, Senior Advocate and Ms Rukmini Bobde, Advocate for their able assistance as Amicus Curiae in the matter. 3 c2012) 10 sec 303: c2012) 4 sec (Civ) 1188: (2013) 1 sec (Cri) 160: c2012) 2 sec (L&S) 988 b C d e f g h
